reviewText: Sound of drop - fall into poison -It is a remake of Sound of Drop
date:
originally released on May 2014. Most of the graphics have been updated, and new scenarios have been added.
It is not a cutesy high school romance visual novel. It is a gripping, disturbing tale of horror which takes place within an aquarium for those who love the horror genre this will suit your taste perfectly.
The secrets of the Manten Aquarium will be revealed!

The storyThe visual novel starts off with Himeno sharing a urban legend off Manten Aquriam with Mayumi as we are introduced to two best friends Mayu and Himeno. Himeno likes paranormal related things and suggests they head to the Manten Aquarium even though Mayu wants nothing to do with the Manten Aquarium but they decided to visit Manten Aquarium to investigate these urban legends. But then...
They caught a glimpse of Mayu’s missing little sister, Mari that disappeared at Manten Aquarium 5 years ago.

Taking place at the heart of Tokyo, the quaint little aquarium, Manten Aquarium. Numerous urban legends have arisen from here. According to rumors passed throughout the student body, this location is filled with all sorts of paranormal activity alongside with more serious things like unexplained disappearances and deaths AND supposedly, there are things like a fish with a human face and that the aquarium water turns to blood on full moons.

Manten AquariumAn urban aquarium inconspicuously settled inside Manten East Building. It is situated on the top floor of the section protruding outward, utilizing a sturdy steel frame. There was once an esteemed Deep-sea Fish booth, but it was closed down approximately five years ago.

Audio and Visual elementsVisual elements - are absolutely stunning the background are smooth, while glommy colors are being put to use to set up the overall creepy atmosphere.
Event CG are extremely detailed, the CG alone have the ability to depict the overall environment.
Chibi art of the characters are cute and sprites are detailed.

Audio elements - are PERFECT soundtracks used, fits in perfectly into the creepy atmosphere, and honestly it made me felt a chill down my spine, yes I honestly felt scared when playing this because of the creepy music. I loved the part where you start up the game and you are immediately greeted with a atmospheric and soothing music with a girl seemed that seems to be Mayumi somewhat drowning these 2 things the menu music and Mayumi drowning compliments with each other so well together.
There is no voice acting in this visual novel regardless despite not having voice actors it still manages to strike fear into the reader hearts with just soundtracks and backgrounds.

To sum upSound of Drop – fall into poison – is an impressive visual novel for how it manages to utterly disturb players with simple text and artwork with creepy music. People who loves the horror genre even if they’ve never played a visual novel before I am very sure you will enjoy this visual novel.

reviewText:
Some Possible Spoilers:

Sound of Drop - fall into poison - is a magnificent horror/mystery visual novel that drags the reader into a dimensional rift within an Aquarium. You take the role of Nakanobe Mayumi who goes with her friend Tamagawa Himeno to the Manten Aquarium to learn about the many rumors of the place. Do to certain incidents that happen while there, Mayu ends up having to work her way through the altered Aquarium in order to save her best friend.

The story for the game is very well done and actually has some cultural beliefs that connect the altered/dimensional world to the real world. I won't go into too much detail but it is related to the Moon and portals. The story was well set up with the many choices. You have different colored choices, Red usually meaning that it will lead to a possible bad ending, and blue which are calming moments that give you a chance to breath and pick whatever you want without ruining your story. The choices vary through out the story. You will sometimes have a choice followed by another choice which actually works with your decision making choices during the different scenes. Then you may get some free time before your next choice to get the story and how the characters are feeling about what just happened. This gives the player a chance to calm down after an event and try to focus back on the story some more. There were actually very few, if any, grammer and spelling mistakes that I encountered (I can recall a few, but they did not really interfere with the story). The steam edition actually added more content to the story and reading the main story and then going to New Game + actually adds even more story that helps to complete more questions you may have had from the first playthrough. I actually think the addition was very well done and made for an even better experience.

The music choice is also very well done. The opening and ending songs for both the main and new game + are very good and add to the atmosphere. The music switches based on what is going on in the aquarium. The darker scenes have scarier, more heavily tones notes that emphasize something bad is approaching, while the calmer scenes have softer notes that bring some calm to the reader. The music greatly adds to the atmosphere so that the reader will be tensed up in the darker moments and be able to calm down and be ready for the next event when they are calming down with the softer sides.

There are only a few downsides to the game that lower the experience of the game. Even though the music is very well done, a few of the songs are a little repetative and can get a little tiring to listen to. Even these songs add to the atmosphere, but they can also make you not want to listen to them anymore. I would take my headphones off every so often because I got a little tired of hearing them. Now, granted, I am a slow reader so I tend to hear a song loop many times compared to most readers. So it may not actually bother most people.

Another downside is the choices. The story is pretty linear with the choices. Usually only one choice is right and if you dont pick that, then you will get a bad ending. There are very few choices that actually change the course of the ending, and most of those are mid to late game. However, some of the endings you get are actually not that bad. A couple are repeats (even though they are considered different ending), and can just be a bit dull to deal with. Yet, there are quite a few that are adding to the story. I think getting some of the bad endings actually adds to the story and makes it a bit better. The New game + choices actually lead to a slightly better ending, but there are not as many new choices in the add on content compaired to the main story. That also deters some people in the long run. You may be playing and getting choices but then suddenly have no choice for 30 minutes. They are using that time usually to tell the story, which is well needed, but it changes your pattern and thought process. You were picking choicese every 5-10 minutes and then suddenly you are given a choice 30 -45 minutes later.

In the long run, this Visual Novel is probably one of the best VN's I've read in a while and I would highly recommend it. The soundtrack is suppose to be added some time in the future and I would gladly say you pick that up if you enjoy the music in the game. There may not be voice acting, but as a Sound Novel, the atmosphere is well done with the music and no VA. I think the VA would hinder the game a little. The story and the idea of the altered aquarium actually make the game well worth reading and enjoyable. If you are into the horror/mystery visual novels, I would recommend. Note: there is blood and there is horror, so be advised that you may not want to let younger viewers or even yourself read this if you do not like these kinds of things.

Highly Recommended 9.0/10

I guess I originally got this because I had a good feeling about it as a Japanese horror title.  Historically, I've found there's a certain vibe to visual novel horror that isn't really present in anything else, with a gloomy, oppressive type of tone.

Well, I admit the actual horror scenes, when examined by themselves, do a pretty good job of creating that type of atmosphere.  It relies on evoking the type of horror you would actually experience in encountering certain dangerous creatures in real life, and it combines it with a warped physical reality as described by a dazed, confused narrator, such that everything feels like being stuck in a nightmare come to life.

But this all stopped mattering to me pretty quickly because the rest of the story is so stupid.

Usually I'm willing to let a story get away with a lot of things as long as it can play up its emotions well enough.  In the case of this particular story, though, it's just too distracting.  Every time you make the correct series of lucky guesses necessary to survive a particular dangerous event, you are rewarded with an expositional plot dump.  That probably would have done well to play up the story's mystery aspects if this was a different story, but in this case, there IS no mystery.  It's ghosts, okay?  Everything's caused by ghosts.  If anything weird happens, a ghost did it.  There's no joy to be had in analyzing the story when it's already established that there's no logic or consistency to any of it.

Again, I'd probably even be okay with that as long as the emotions were played well enough, but it turns out the only emotion the story plays well is horror.  The characters are all one-note, only there to serve functional roles within the story (hero, villain, sidekick, damsel, etc.) rather than be actual people.  The story attempts to create drama, but it does it mainly by explaining that the characters are upset about what's happening, rather than demonstrating why they would be.

Why is this teenage schoolgirl crying after her close friend went running off down the hallway to chase something?  Why is this enough to end their friendship?  How am I supposed to believe that they're close friends in the first place if this is enough to end their friendship, and I have no other information about their relationship other than one girl tends to get pushed around by the other as it is? Why is the other schoolgirl now trying to save a ghost from being killed when the ghost is already dead, and the schoolgirl herself acknowledges that this doesn't make any sense?  Why is there a load-bearing boss in this non-action story!? I don't know, but you better get worked up about it, because the story tension is depending on it!  Drama!!

The horror is good, but even if the horror is good, it's hard to really be affected by it if you don't relate to the characters.  And it's hard to get from one horror scene to the next if, in between each one, you have to rapidly click through several minutes of dialogue while going uuuugghhhh".

And I would probably even forgive all that if the choice system was better.  Sometimes I like visual novels just because your choices lead to branching paths

I was pleasantly surprised by how invested I became with this game and how much it stuck with me afterwards, especially considering the best of the visual novels I’ve played so far have been sound/kinetic ones not choice based. And as a fan of horror in any medium it is a real treat to see a visual novel create such a great horror atmosphere. I couldn’t wait to try each decision I’d left before and find the new ending, especially as there were several choices that threw me off completely (examining the cutlass-fish anyone?). And these bad endings are horrifying at times, the detail in which these are written is utterly amazing and more than once I was staring at the screen in awe at how brutal and disturbing these could get, and a couple of times it’s difficult to tell if this is a bad ending or if Miyu can turn it around at the last minute. That’s story-writing I am very envious of. I had not originally purchased the soundtrack but after a hundred percenting the game I immediately grabbed it at the end of the sale as the music is just beautiful, especially that amazing opening song.

However the biggest thing that really pushed Sound of Drop above and beyond for me personally is its replay-ability. I imagine there are at least one or two people like me who make a save at every choice and when the story is over, go back to each individual choice and make the opposite decision. I very rarely replay visual novels from the beginning unless there’s a section I didn’t save for, as I can usually get all the endings/achievements just by going back to the decisions saved. But after doing that thoroughly there were several bad endings and a couple of true endings I didn’t have yet, no matter what I did. So I finally started from the beginning again and not only was I treated to a completely new opening scene that developed one character and introduced another, but this actually changed a few aspects of the main plotline, it was an amazing experience.

Overall a fantastic visual novel and just a fantastic game in general, I can only hope to find more horror games that are this creative in their execution.

The game is a visual novel where you play as Mayumi, alongside her friend Himeno.

Mayumi is your shy, good girl, indoor type of character with a tiny bit of a dark past.

Himeno, on the other hand, is your outgoing, social butterfly, with a weird sense of humor.

The game starts off with Himeno sharing, an urban legend about the Manten Aquarium.
The legend entais unexplained disappearances, deaths, and of course water turning into blood on full moon.

The story is about the adventure these two polar opposites of friends got involved in, while trying to investigate the urban legend, with the pretext of hanging out one last time before the big test.

The wheel of fate starts to turn when Mari, Mayumi's missing little sister, appears.

The art of the game is not like your cutesy, adorable visual novels, but the game does have its fair share of cutesy sprites and chibis.
But don't be folled, there's a doom and gloom atmosphere that will constanly reminds you what this game really is.
Backgrounds and sprites aside, the CGs were detailed and downright fearful.

The music were wisely used. Ranging from jauntily lighthearted in one scene to downright frightening in the next.
Fitting and enhancing the already creepy atmosphere.

I would like to note that the characters are not voiced, but that does not take anything away from the game

To sum up, the game is surpringly good, with is engaging haunting storyline, likeable cast and disturbing content to go along with its vivid CGs and many many bad ends. A fitting game to play on Halloween. I rate it a 4 out of 5.

reviewText:
I came into this VN expecting two things: Some kind of quality comparable to previous Sekai Project titles (I’m riding the Sekai Project hype train) and a mazelike, non-linear experience (since that is what it advertised itself as).  Unfortunately, the game failed to deliver on these fronts.  I sparingly read visual novels, however, and doubtless that influences this review.  For those of you who are in the tl;dr crowd, just skip to the last paragraph.  All spoilers in this review are properly tagged, so it can be read spoiler free.


What I got was a very linear experience.  Keep in mind, when I say linear I mean linear in the context of the visual novel genre.  Linear games are not a problem; the issue here is that the game poses itself as one that offers you a lot of choice when the nature of the game is simply just giving you the ILLUSION of choice.  It’s false advertising on the game’s part.  Why?

There are three types of choices in this game.  The first kind of choice are the ones with red boxes which show you “do or die” situations, so they are all are meaningful towards your progression through the game.  Failing to choose the right decision leads to a bad end, and all bad ends are short and immediate.  Indeed, the game is in no way a maze.  You could easily get through purely by quicksaving at every red choice.  The second kind of choice are one with blue boxes which are non-branching and thus not meaningful.  The final kind of choice are the very rare, seen only once per playthrough single blue box choices, one with an actual lasting affect game that determines which “true end” you receive.  The true endings are not meaningful since they are only determined by this single choice, even if its midway through the game.  The late game true endings are less meaningful and interesting because of their redundancy of the first set of the early game endings.  In the early game, this choice seems like an inconsequential afterthought by Mayumi when it’s presented as well.  The choice doesn't even branch how the story ends up playing out, besides tone of the epilogue and maybe a few paragraphs of text immediately after the choice.  So yeah, the game is very linear on the early side of things.  On the late game side, the game becomes slightly less linear by branching in two general directions, one towards the early game true endings and the other towards the late game true endings.

Since the game is linear, most of the choices will not feel meaningful towards the outcome of the plot, just your ability to progress through it.  This makes the choice system itself feel underwhelming, to the point where the choices simply become puzzles, traps to avoid death.  Unfortunately, most of the choices are dominated by simple common sense or logic, so they are very easy puzzles.  You will likely never hesitate to make a single choice throughout the entire game, and you probably won’t make any wrong ones either.  However, there is one choice in the beginning that is completely counterintuitive (It’s the choice with the jellyfish).  I’m pretty sure it’s just there to troll you, making you think twice about using common sense in the future, despite common sense being your best tool in the game.  Getting a wrong choice will not reward you beyond the process of elimination, because…

The plot is your run of the mill haunted house story, this time set in an aquarium.  It features one genuine satisfying “WTF” moment Soya’s death, a few minor plot inconsistencies, and copious amounts of fridge logic and hand waves.  The game isn't scary, there are no jumpscares; the most it manages is an intermittent, mildly creepy or cringy mood.  The deaths are not entertaining; most of them end up being cookie cutter.  It’s REALLY hurt since the main character's Mayumi’s reactions to death (especially her own) are very underwhelming.  For a horror visual novel it’s surprisingly light on the drama, and this was the most disappointing aspect of the game for me.  If anything, it attempts to be more of a heart-string tugger than most horror stories end up being, but falls flat on its face some the characters are so utterly boring and their words and intentions so hollow.

In order to unlock the game past 50% some unintuitive 4th wall breaking is required.  Unfortunately that is one of the worse staples of the VN genre in my strong opinion.  Its presence here was not hinted at in the slightest.  I had to take off additional points for this dubious mechanic.

By the time I 100%ed the game, one thing was clear to me.  None of the endings felt unique; they are all just different ways to essentially get the same ending.  The endings that require more work don’t feel more rewarding than the ones that require less work either because the people you “save” are not likeable characters and the ways and reasons you save them feel utterly redundant for their longer length.  As such, completing the game felt significantly underwhelming and like a large waste of time.  Once you get one ending you’ve gotten them all, unless you want those miniscule deviations in plot or if you want the game to explain everything to you.  Unfortunately, the explanation isn’t worth the time it takes to read it, as pretty much all it did (for me at least) was confirm all the guesswork I had up until that point, and I’m willing to bet others would have similar experiences.

I found it particularly annoying that, when trying to collect the bad endings, you can’t skip the two ending animations, so you’ll be waiting for 20 seconds staring at a blank imagery waiting to farm the next bad ending.

The music score is mediocre and loops relatively quickly.  Its not bad though, and succeeds in capturing the mood at various points in the game.

I have to take away points on CG-plot inconsistencies, especially since they were pretty numerous.  If you want some examples, take a look at my game screenshots, quite a few of them are pointing them out.  The quality checking really could have been more diligent.

It should also be mentioned that there were parts of the game that felt very poorly conveyed.  Some moments ideas seem way too abstract, and on others characters' identities seem to blur as they talk to themselves or the void or soliloque, WHILE being abstract.  Its not clear whether this was entirely intentional or due to translation errors, and the lack of clarity or resolution in this respect distracts from the mood of the game.  You're stuck sitting there trying to figure out what in the world was said half the time.  The game also seems to want you to play the later half in a particular order, as not doing so will seriously confuse you.

On the bright side, Mari-chan is cute!  I did want to save her, for at least the first ending / playthrough.  Game did a good job of convincing you to do that, at least.  Unfortunately, most of the other characters (including Mayumi) end up being uninteresting and two dimensional, likely a byproduct of the distinct lack of drama and conflict resolution in this novel.  Not to mention, the repeated attempts and similar endings pretty much trashed any interest I had in repeatedly saving Mari.

In conclusion, Poison Drop is towards the worse end of mediocrity.  It doesn’t measure up to my expected quality standards from Sekai Project, and it also drew me in with false expectations of a non-linear, maze-like experience.  It’s likely a Halloween cash grab by Sekai Project, actually.  As such, I cannot recommend it beyond being a cheap, light-horror way to spend Halloween and the end of Fall.

That's not to say it wasn't good, the protagonist was fun to be & the other characters were actually pretty good. I'd recommend it if you're already acquainted with  VN's or if you're looking for a darker mystery story.

Sound of Drop - fall into poison - was just one of those games that happened to catch my eye in a Steam sale. So no pressure: I went in with zero expectations.

First off: artwork and CG scenes are beautifully rendered. The characters each have a distinct personality and everyone's there for a reason. While there are some cliches, they don't detract from the story. There's a hefty number of endings, all of which are worth seeing (well... maybe aside from some of the bad ones...). I have a newfound interest in aquariums now.

The themes addressed are fairly deep, and the true endings do resonate with you for a while. You might find yourself pondering certain concepts Mayu (the protagonist) is exposed to. Horror elements in the game don't come from jump scares (thankfully), and the use of colours throughout the storytelling helps unify the visual novel as a whole.

Tl;dr: GET! Worth playing and replaying until you've seen all the endings. Manten Aquarium definitely has a special place in my heart, too.
I don't usually go for horror games, but between the awesome soundtrack and interesting storyline I enjoyed this one.

Still, I would recommend this visual novel. I really enjoyed reading it.

Despite the fact there are no CVs, I'm probably going to enjoy this VN a lot.

This is a placeholder review as I only dipped my foot into the game so far. But I feel that so far the game warrants a positive recommendation to visual novel/horror fans.

The use of effects, both sound and visual, helps add to the scares and atmosphere. There is no voice acting, but the music is good, particularly the addictive opening.
The characters seem to be pretty well written, and while the designs aren't going to blow your socks off, they are well drawn and look appropriate for their roles. The setting is interesting, and so far the plot is intriguing enough to want to play more and the horror is pretty well doen in my opinion.
I should mention, as you might have been told, that there are a lot of bad ends in the game. Though I am not not sure how much gore is really in the game, but the one bad end I got so far (of which there are many) was fairly brutual in it's description, but not very graphic. Hopefully the other endings are more graphic.

A friend recommended me to take a look at visual novel's. at first I had my doubts and didn't seriously think about trying one. you can say I was more afraid that I wouldn't get into it but alas it was the opposite .

today the anime industry suffers as it is dealing with self blows by having a lot of awkward ecchi moments that would even embarrass you're mom. now don't get me wrong. when it is well executed and done well and not being repeated stupidly then it would be acceptable. sadly the industry has seen its need to use it as means of survival as sales of bluray and dvd sets are just awful and having to rely on people buying merchandise just makes the anime industry in bad shape. maybe we will even witness the fall of this industry as it has it's setbacks and such that I won't discuss now but all we can do is support the studio's that keep producing you're favorite series.

But with this visual novel its different. the mystery feeling that you get , the creepy soundtrack which did an amazing job just sucking you into the creepy atmosphere of manten aquarium , the horror element is there to get you scared and the adventure element is there to make it a complete package to explore and enjoy,the story on its own is written very well and made me have my share of fear and connection with the characters and really understanding what they are going through at the moment, I don't really want to spoil anything but its better for you to check out at least the demo version and get a better hang of what are you gonna play.

would recommend for everyone who was a spare of 10-15 hours to read and go through all the endings which are worth to check out and also pick an ending who is the most suitable for you.
